(a)
Right of entry. The utilities manager and other authorized utility employees may enter and have free access to any residence or structure where utility service is connected or supplied for the purpose of reading or maintenance of meters. Entry will be made during normal business hours of 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, unless unusual or emergency circumstances require otherwise. If entry is required at other times, the utilities manager or other authorized utility employee will give notice to a property owner or tenant before entering the property.
(b)
Inspection and sampling. The utilities manager or an authorized utility employee shall have the right to enter the premises of any utility user to determine whether the utility user is complying with all requirements of this chapter and the utility regulations of the city and with any wastewater discharge permit or order issued under this chapter or pursuant to the rules and regulations governing the municipal utilities. Utility users must allow ready access to all parts of the premises for the purpose of inspection, sampling and the performance of any additional duties. In addition, the utilities manager or an authorized employee of the utility may require the following:
(1)
The right to set up on the utility user's property, or require installation of, such devices as are necessary to conduct sampling and/or metering of the utility user's operations.
(2)
The right to require the utility user to install monitoring equipment as necessary, which shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition by the utility user at the user's own expense. All devices used to measure wastewater flow and quality shall be calibrated to ensure their accuracy.
(3)
Any temporary or permanent installation that hampers convenient access to the facility to be inspected and/or sampled shall promptly be removed by the utility user at the written or verbal request of the utilities manager or an authorized utility employee. The cost of clearing such access shall be borne by the utility user.
(4)
Unreasonable delays in allowing the utilities manager or an authorized utility employee access to the utility user's premises is a violation of this chapter.
(c)
Inspection or search warrant. If the utilities manager or an authorized utility employee has been refused access to a building, structure, property, or any part thereof, and is able to demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of this chapter or of the rules or regulations governing the municipal utilities, or that there is a need to inspect and/or sample as part of a routine inspection and sampling program of the city designed to verify compliance with this chapter or any permit or order issued under this chapter, or to protect the overall public health, safety and welfare of the city, then the utilities manager or an authorized utility employee may seek issuance of either an inspection warrant or a search warrant from a magistrate or circuit court judge of the Third Judicial Circuit located in Brookings County, South Dakota.

(a)
No person may discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water, groundwater or untreated industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. At no time shall the abovementioned water be allowed to be pumped or drained to any sanitary sewer except that stormwater, surface water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water and groundwater may be pumped or drained into the sanitary sewer from October 15 through March 15.
(b)
No person may make connections of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.
(c)
If sump pumps are required for floor drains only, the sump pump must be properly trapped and connected directly to the sanitary sewer.
(d)
Where there is a sump pump located for the purpose of drainage of surface or subsurface water, all new residential or commercial construction shall have a pump discharge installed and connected to a drainage facility other than the sanitary sewer.

Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the city.

Sec. 86-84. - Prohibited wastes.
SHARE LINK TO SECTION
PRINT SECTION
DOWNLOAD (DOCX) OF SECTIONS
EMAIL SECTION
COMPARE VERSIONS
(a)
Except as provided in this section, no person may discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any municipal sewer:
(1)
Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit.
(2)
Any water or waste which may contain more than 100 parts per million, by weight, of fat, oil or grease.
(3)
Any gasoline, benzine, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas.
(4)
Any garbage that has not been properly shredded.
(5)
Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, paunch manure or any other solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewerage system.
(6)
Any waters or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, or which constitute a hazard to humans or animals or which create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewerage treatment plant.
(7)
Any waters or waste containing suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the sewage treatment plant.
(8)
Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a public nuisance.
(b)
Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the utilities manager or the manager's authorized representative, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any inflammable wastes, sand and other harmful ingredients. However, such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the utilities manager or the manager's authorized representative, and shall be located so they may be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection.
(c)
Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight and equipped with easily removable covers which when bolted in place shall be gastight and watertight.
(d)
All grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at the owner's expense, and shall be in continuously efficient operation at all times.
(e)
No person or local government unit may discharge or cause or allow to be discharged into the city disposal system or any connected disposal system any wastes which will cause the influent flow of the wastewater treatment plant to exceed the concentrations set forth in the sewer use rules and regulations as described in section 86-85.
(Code 1996, § 35-84)

(a)
Except as provided in this section, no person may discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any municipal sewer:
(1)
Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit.
(2)
Any water or waste which may contain more than 100 parts per million, by weight, of fat, oil or grease.
(3)
Any gasoline, benzine, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas.
(4)
Any garbage that has not been properly shredded.
(5)
Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, paunch manure or any other solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewerage system.
(6)
Any waters or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, or which constitute a hazard to humans or animals or which create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewerage treatment plant.
(7)
Any waters or waste containing suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the sewage treatment plant.
(8)
Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of creating a public nuisance.
(b)
Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the utilities manager or the manager's authorized representative, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any inflammable wastes, sand and other harmful ingredients. However, such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the utilities manager or the manager's authorized representative, and shall be located so they may be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection.
(c)
Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight and equipped with easily removable covers which when bolted in place shall be gastight and watertight.
(d)
All grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at the owner's expense, and shall be in continuously efficient operation at all times.
(e)
No person or local government unit may discharge or cause or allow to be discharged into the city disposal system or any connected disposal system any wastes which will cause the influent flow of the wastewater treatment plant to exceed the concentrations set forth in the sewer use rules and regulations as described in section 86-85.

PREFACE
This Code constitutes a republication of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Selby, South Dakota.
Source materials used in the preparation of the republication were the City Code, as updated through 2021. The source of each new section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is part of the 1989 Municipal Code Book. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this republication, the reader can locate any section of the Code, as updated.
Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this republication.
Chapter and Section Numbering System
The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of three parts separated by periods. The figure before the first period refers to the title number, the figure after the first period refers to the chapter within the title, and the figure after the second period refers to the section within the chapter. Thus, the first section of the second chapter of the first title is numbered 1.02.010. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and each chapter is identified with its title and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 1.02.010 and 1.02.020 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 1.02.015. If new material is to be added to the end of a title a new chapter may be added.
Page Numbering System
The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a title of the republication, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the title. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this republication at this time, and their corresponding prefixes:
EXPAND

RELATED LAWS RL:1
SPECIAL ACTS SA:1

RELATED LAWS COMPARATIVE TABLE RLCT:1
SPECIAL ACTS COMPARATIVE TABLE SACT:1

CODE APPENDIX CDA:1
CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1
STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1
CHARTER INDEX CHTi:1
CODE INDEX CDi:1
  Index or Indexes
The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested.
Looseleaf Supplements
A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up to date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages.
Keeping this publication up to date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes.

This republication was under the direct supervision of Cristine Dawson, Editor, and Erin Bowen, Proofreader, of Civicplus, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project.
The publisher is most grateful to Ms. Vickie Schulkoski, for her cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this republication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a republication of this Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the borough readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

Title 2 - ADMINISTRATIVE CODE
Loading complete

A.
Regular meetings. The regular meetings of the city council shall be held on the first Monday of each month, commencing at the hour of 7:00 p.m. The council may change the meeting date and time for its regular meeting provided the same is done at the previous regular meeting by a motion duly passed.
B.
Special meetings. The mayor or acting mayor of the city is hereby authorized and empowered to call special meeting of the city council at any time when, in the judgment of the mayor, the same may be deemed necessary, and it is hereby made the duty of such officer to call such special meeting whenever requested to do so by a majority of the aldermen of the city. And in case of any special meeting, personal notice thereof shall be given to all aldermen not absent from the city, before such meeting shall be opened.
C.
Effect of business of special meetings. All business done at a special meeting called in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall have the same force an legal effect as if done at a regular meeting of the city council, except as otherwise provided by law.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 167 on 7/1/2002; Amended by Ord. 214 on 6/4/2012)
State Law reference— SDCL ch. 9-8 generally.

A.
Salaries and compensation. The salaries and compensation of municipal officers, and the mayor, acting mayor, and aldermen of the City of Selby, South Dakota arc to be fixed at the rates determined by the aldermen themselves in a proclamation which in turn is to be signed by the mayor, or acting mayor, before taking effect. This section does not affect current amounts in use prior to its passing. The amount may be paid in any manner at any time the above-mentioned officials choose when drafting the proclamation. The said proclamation shall then be published for at least two weeks in a local newspaper.
B.
Compensation for special meetings. The mayor, acting mayor, and each alderman, shall in addition to the above compensation, be paid the sum for council members as determined by resolution of the council from time to time and a sum for the mayor as determined by resolution of the council from time to time for each special meeting attended and called by the mayor or acting mayor.
C.
Vacancy in office of mayor. That in the event of vacancy in the office of city mayor, the president of the council as acting mayor shall receive the salary of mayor, but shall not receive his salary as alderman, while acting as mayor.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 167 on 7/1/2002; Amended by Ord. 214 on 6/4/2012)
State Law reference— SDCL ch. 9-8 generally.

A.
Pursuant to SDCL 9-21-34, the annual municipal budget ordinance shall be submitted to the city council no later than the first regular meeting in November.
B.
The second reading of the annual municipal budget ordinances shall be held at least five days after the first reading.
C.
The annual municipal budget ordinance shall be published prior to December 31 following adoption.
( Ord. No. 2021-06 , § I, 9-1-2021)

The City of Selby, is divided into three wards as follows:
The first ward includes all the territory within the corporate limits commencing at a point at the intersection of First Avenue and South Dakota Highway 130, thence commencing south on First Avenue one block to the intersection of Theodore Street and First Avenue, thence commencing east on Theodore Street two blocks to the intersection of Third Avenue and Theodore Street, thence commencing south on Third Avenue to Walworth Street, then commencing west one block on Walworth to Second street. Then commencing South one block on Second Avenue to Bangor. Then commencing two blocks east on Bangor to Main Street. Then south to South Railway to the Southern corporate city limits.
The second ward includes all territory within the corporate limits lying north of a line drawn through the center of South Dakota Highway 130 and extending east from the center of Highway 130 to the east line of the corporation and west from the centerline of Highway 130 to the west line of the corporate limits of Selby. Including the first blocks on First and Second Ave to Theodore Street from Highway 130.
The third ward includes all territory within the corporate limits of Selby commencing at a point on South Dakota Highway 130 which is on the west end of the corporate limits of Selby commencing east on Highway 130, to the intersection of Highway 130 and Third Avenue thence commencing south on Third Avenue two blocks to the intersection of Walworth Street and Third Avenue, thence commencing east on Walworth Street one block to the intersection of Walworth Street and Second Avenue, thence commencing south to Bangor. Then commencing south on main street to South Railway Road. Thence commencing east on south railway street to the then eastern corporate city limits of Selby, thence commencing west to the southwest corner of the city limits of Selby, thence commencing north to Highway 10, the point of beginning.

The first, second and third wards or the city are hereby consolidated for voting purposes provided that at any election at which aldermen are to be elected, there shall be a separate ballot for each ward, and the vote of each elector voting at such election shall be deposited for his own ward, and the vote for alderman in each ward shall be counted and canvassed separately.

State Law reference— SDCL ch. 9-13 generally.

There is created a recreation board for the city to be known as the Selby Recreation Board, to establish, improve care for, regulate and manage a system of public recreation.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

The recreation board shall have all of those powers and be subject to the limitations and enjoy those privileges and immunities all as provided for by SDCL ch. 9-38 as now or hereafter amended. Whenever the approval of the governing body is required before the recreation board can act, such prior approval shall be first obtained. Otherwise, the board shall be charged with the supervision and management of recreational functions.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

Upon the final adoption and publication of the ordinance in this chapter, the mayor with the approval of the governing body, shall appoint five members to the recreation board, each of whom shall be a resident and freeholder of the community. One such member shall be appointed for one year, two for two years, two for three years, and thereafter each appointment shall be for three years. Such appointees are to hold off ice until their successors are appointed and qualified. The sixth member of the board shall be a city councilman appointed by the mayor.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

At the first regular meeting of the city council in May of each year the members shall be appointed or reappointed by the mayor and approved by the governing body for a term of three years to succeed the retiring members.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

At the first regular meeting of the recreation board after the final adoption and publication of the ordinance, the board shall elect from its number, excluding the city councilman on the board, a president, a vice president, and a secretary-treasurer, each of whom shall serve until the first meeting in August of each year. The vice-president shall act in the absence or disability of the president. In case of the death or retirement of an officer, a successor shall be elected immediately.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

With the approval of the governing body, the recreation board may appoint a director of the recreation department. This individual shall hold off ice at the pleasure of the board and receive such salary as the governing body may determine and shall on behalf of the recreation board and governing body charge, supervision and direction of all activities.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

Any vacancy on the recreation board shall be filled for the unexpired term of any member vacating such board for any reason or purpose in the same manner as is required for a regular appointment.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

All members appointed to serve on the recreation board shall serve without compensation except for expenses accrued due to authorized travel outside the city in fulfilling the obligations of their appointed duties. The expenses shall be reimbursed on the basis of actual proof of personal expenses accrued due to and during such authorized travel.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

The board shall hold regular meetings as it deems proper and necessary to conduct the official business affairs of the recreation department. Three members constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, but an affirmative vote of at least three members shall be necessary to authorize any official action of the board.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

Any recommendation of the recreation board to the governing body shall be by resolution. When an ordinance of the governing body is passed upon the recommendation of the recreation board, it is not necessary for such ordinance to recite at length the resolution of the recreation board recommending the same, but it is sufficient to recite the fact of such recommendation by such recreation board, which recital shall be conclusive of the making and regularity of such resolution in all proceedings thereafter.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

The members of the recreation board subject to the approval of the governing body, may establish bylaws, rules and regulations for the orderly transactions and conduct of its business and operation of the recreation department facilities.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

The secretary-treasurer of the board shall keep a record of its proceedings and make such reports as may be required by the board. In his absence, or inability to act, the board may appoint a secretary pro tem to perform his duties. The records of such board, kept by its secretary or copies of any such records when duly certified by the secretary shall be competent evidence of the proceedings of the board. Copies of any and all such records and/or reports shall be filed with the city finance officer.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

The recreation board before the first of August of each year shall make an estimate of the moneys necessary for the operation of the city's system of recreation and as authorized by SDCL ch. 9-38. Such estimate shall be certified by the secretary of the recreation board to the city finance officer on or before the first day of August of each year.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

Real or personal property or the income thereof may be granted, bequeathed, devised or conveyed to the city for recreational purposes authorized by SDCL ch. 9-38, and upon such conditions as may be prescribed by the grantors, donors or devisors thereof and agreed to be the governing body and the recreation board.
(Adopted by Ord. 137 on 10/10/1991)

The chief of police shall be, ex-officio, the custodian of the fire house and of all fire trucks and all other fire-fighting apparatus belonging to the city, when not in use.
State Law reference— SDCL ch. 9-33; SDCL 9-33-11; SDCL 9-33-12; SDCL 9-33-13; SDCL 22-11-6.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990)

There shall be appointed, at the regular January meeting of the city council each year, and at other times in case of a vacancy, by the city council, one fire chief and two assistants, to be designated as the rust and second assistants, who shall qualify by taking an oath of office, to be filed with the city auditor within five days after such appointment; said fire chief and first and second assistant fire chiefs, shall hold office during the pleasure of the city council and until their successors are appointed and qualified, and a failure to qualify within the time herein provided, shall cause a vacancy.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990)
State Law reference— SDCL ch. 9-33; SDCL 9-33-11; SDCL 9-33-12; SDCL 9-33-13; SDCL 22-11-6.

It shall be the duty of the fire chief, and in case of his absence or inability to act, of the first assistant fire chief, and in case of the absence or inability to act of both the chief and the first assistant, then of the second assistant fire chief, to assume general control of and supervision over all the fire-fighting apparatus of the city in case of fire or an alarm of fire; to be present at all fires and to respond to all fire alarms and generally to direct and control the operations of all the fire-fighting forces of the city at such times, to the end of preventing an minimizing, so far as possible, losses by fire. And in the performance of said duties, said fire chief or acting fire chief shall have full authority over all property of the city and over all fire companies and fire fighters engaged in the fighting of any fire or preventing its spread. It shall also be the duty of the first and second assistant fire chiefs to assist the fire chief or acting fire chief cooperating with him in the discharge of those duties.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990)
State Law reference— SDCL ch. 9-33; SDCL 9-33-11; SDCL 9-33-12; SDCL 9-33-13; SDCL 22-11-6.

The city council shall keep an accredited list of fire companies of the city, which may be revised at any time by the council. Each member of every accredited company shall be paid from the general funds of the city a sum of $3.35 per hour while engaged in fighting fire under direction of the fire chief or acting fire chief, and, in case of a false alarm, when a person reports in good faith for duty at the firehouse, the sum to be paid depends upon the city council. Said sums are to be paid by warrants, on the verified claim of the captain or other officer in command of such company, presented at the next meeting of the city council after such a fire or an alarm for a fire. The claim shall contain a statement of the names of all members of the company assisting at such fire or reporting for duty on such alarm, and the number of hours worked by each; other persons necessarily employed by the fire chief or acting assistant in times of danger, may be paid as ordinary claims against the city, with the consent of the fire chief or assistant, whoever employed such a person.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990)
State Law reference— SDCL ch. 9-33; SDCL 9-33-11; SDCL 9-33-12; SDCL 9-33-13; SDCL 22-11-6.

Any person interfering with or willfully hindering or preventing the fire chief or assistant while acting as fire chief, in the discharge of his duties, or willfully hindering, interfering with or preventing any fireman while carrying out any order of such chief or assistant, and any fireman willfully refusing to obey any lawful order of the fire chief when engaged in the performance of his duties as prescribed by this chapter, shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $20.00.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990)
Cross reference— SMC §§ 6.04.100 and 6.04.110.
State Law reference— SDCL ch. 9-33; SDCL 9-33-11; SDCL 9-33-12; SDCL 9-33-13; SDCL 22-11-6.

A.
Regular meetings. The regular meetings of the city council shall be held on the first Monday of each month, commencing at the hour of 7:00 p.m. The council may change the meeting date and time for its regular meeting provided the same is done at the previous regular meeting by a motion duly passed.
B.
Special meetings. The mayor or acting mayor of the city is hereby authorized and empowered to call special meeting of the city council at any time when, in the judgment of the mayor, the same may be deemed necessary, and it is hereby made the duty of such officer to call such special meeting whenever requested to do so by a majority of the aldermen of the city. And in case of any special meeting, personal notice thereof shall be given to all aldermen not absent from the city, before such meeting shall be opened.
C.
Effect of business of special meetings. All business done at a special meeting called in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall have the same force an legal effect as if done at a regular meeting of the city council, except as otherwise provided by law.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 167 on 7/1/2002; Amended by Ord. 214 on 6/4/2012)

A.
Salaries and compensation. The salaries and compensation of municipal officers, and the mayor, acting mayor, and aldermen of the City of Selby, South Dakota arc to be fixed at the rates determined by the aldermen themselves in a proclamation which in turn is to be signed by the mayor, or acting mayor, before taking effect. This section does not affect current amounts in use prior to its passing. The amount may be paid in any manner at any time the above-mentioned officials choose when drafting the proclamation. The said proclamation shall then be published for at least two weeks in a local newspaper.

By SDCL ch. 10-52 entitled Uniform Municipal Non-Ad Valorem Tax Law, and acts amendatory thereto.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 185 on 10/3/2005; Amended by Ord. 194 on 3/3/2008)

(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990)

Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions contained in any of the sections of this chapter, shall upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than $5.00 nor more than $100.00, together with the costs of prosecution, for each and every offense.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990)
State Law reference— SDCL 9-34-1; and SDCL 9-19-3.

The City of Selby, South Dakota, hereby authorizes on-sale and off-sale licensees to sell alcoholic beverages during the time frames allowed and pursuant to SDCL 35-4-81 on Sundays and Memorial Day.

A.
Entertainment regulations for those who sell liquor. No "on-sale" licensee or dealer shall allow any gambling or gambling devices in or about the premises covered by the liquor license, or permit any lewd or any indecent entertainment on such premises.
B.
Penalty. (Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990)

A.
General rule. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession any unsealed can, bottle, glass, pitcher, container or package of any kind containing wine, alcohol or beer, whether high point or low point, upon any public street, alley, park, playground or any public place or building without having a valid license for the sale and drinking or consuming of such beer, wine or alcohol upon said premises.
B.
Exceptions. Upon application duly made, the mayor or chief of police may issue a temporary permit for a specific time and place, when and where possession of any unsealed can, bottle, glass, pitcher, container or package may be temporarily permitted as a special occurrence. Such a permit shall be in writing, either signed by the mayor or the chief of police.
C.
Penalty. Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of $100.00, or 30 days imprisonment, or both.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990)

The city council of the City of Selby enacts the following licensing ordinances in order to ensure that cannabis establishments within the municipal boundaries of the city operate in a manner which complies with state laws and regulations, protects the health, safety, and welfare of the general public, prevents potential conflicts and issues arising from ownership and employees, recognizes certain safety and security considerations, and minimizes risk of unauthorized use or access of cannabis by the general public.
( Ord. No. 2021-11 , 9-6-2021)

Unless an alternative definition is explicitly stated in this section, this chapter utilizes the definitions for cannabis-related terms which are defined by SDCL 34-20G-1.
Cannabis (or marijuana): All parts of any plant of the genus cannabis, whether growing or not, in its natural and unaltered state, except for drying or curing and crushing or crumbling. The term includes an altered state of marijuana absorbed into the human body. The term does not include fiber produced from the mature stalks of such plant, or oil or cake made from the seeds of such plant. The term does not include the plant Cannabis sativa L. and any part of that plant, including the seeds thereof and all derivatives, extracts, cannabinoids, isomers, acids, salts, and salts of isomers, whether growing or not, with a delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol concentration of not more than three-tenths of one percent on a dry weight basis.
Cannabis cultivation facility: In addition to the definition in SDCL 34-20G-1, this term is further defined as a legally licensed entity that acquires, possesses, cultivates, delivers, transfers, transports, supplies, or sells cannabis and related supplies to a cannabis establishment.
Cannabis dispensary: In addition to the definition in SDCL 34-20G-1, this term is further defined as a legally licensed entity that acquires, possesses, stores, delivers, transfers, transports, sells, supplies, or dispenses cannabis, cannabis products, paraphernalia, or related supplies and educational materials.
Cannabis establishment: Cannabis cultivation facility, a cannabis testing facility, a cannabis product manufacturing facility, or a cannabis dispensary.
Cannabis product manufacturing facility: In addition to the definition in SDCL 34-20G-1, this term is further defined as a legally licensed entity that acquires, possesses, manufactures, delivers, transfers, transports, supplies, or sells cannabis products to a cannabis dispensary.
Cannabis products: Any concentrated cannabis, cannabis extracts, and products that are infused with cannabis or an extract thereof, and are intended for use or consumption by humans. The term includes edible cannabis products, beverages, topical products, ointments, oils, and tinctures.
Cannabis testing facility: In addition to the definition in SDCL 34-20G-1, this term is further defined as a legally licensed entity legally authorized to analyze the safety and potency of cannabis.
Department: The South Dakota Department of Health
( Ord. No. 2021-11 , 9-6-2021)

A.
No cannabis establishment may be located or operate in the city without the appropriate valid and current cannabis establishment license issued by the city pursuant to this article. A violation of this provision is subject to the general penalty provision in section 5.16.160 Each day of the violation constitutes a separate offense.
B.
No cannabis establishment may be located or operate in the city without the appropriate valid and current cannabis establishment registration certificate issued by the department pursuant to rules promulgated under SDCL ch. 34-20G. A violation of this provision is subject to the general penalty provision in section 5.16.160. Each day of the violation constitutes a separate offense.
( Ord. No. 2021-11 , 9-6-2021)

A.
An application for a cannabis establishment license must be made on a form provided by the city. No other application form will be considered.
B.
The applicant must submit the following:
1.
Application fee of $5,000.00. The city will reimburse $2,500.00 for applicants who fail to obtain a registration certificate from the South Dakota Department of Health.
2.
An application that will include, but is not limited to, the following:
(a)
The legal name of the prospective cannabis establishment;
(b)
The physical address of the prospective cannabis establishment that meets the zoning requirements in title 16, as well as any location requirements pursuant SDCL ch. 34-20G and the administrative rules promulgated thereunder.
(c)
The name, address, and birth date of each principal officer, owner, and board member of the proposed cannabis establishment.
(d)
A sworn statement that no principal officer, owner, or board member has been convicted of a violent felony offense in the previous ten years in any jurisdiction.
(e)
Any additional information requested by the city.
( Ord. No. 2021-11 , 9-6-2021)

A.
The city will issue a license unless:
1.
The applicant has made a false statement on the application or submits false records or documentation; or
2.
Any owners, principal officer, or board member of the applicant is under the age of 21 years; or
3.
Any owner, principal officer, or board member of the applicant has been convicted of a violent felony offense in the previous ten years in any jurisdiction;
4.
The proposed location does not meet the applicable zoning requirements under this chapter;
5.
The proposed location does not meet all location requirements under SDCL ch. 34-20G and the administrative rules promulgated thereunder;
6.
The license is to be used for a business prohibited by state or local law, statute, rule, ordinance, or regulation; or
7.
Any owner, principal officer, or board member of the applicant has had a cannabis establishment license revoked by the city or a registration certificate revoked by the state; or
8.
An applicant, or an owner, principal officer, or board member thereof, is overdue in payment to the city of taxes, fees, fines, or penalties assessed against or imposed upon the applicant in relation to any cannabis establishment; or
9.
The applicant will not be operating the business for which the license would be issued.
B.
In the case of an application for a cannabis dispensary license, the city will reject the application if the limit on the number of cannabis dispensaries has been reached.
C.
The license must be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance to the cannabis establishment so that it may be easily read at any time.
( Ord. No. 2021-11 , 9-6-2021)

Upon request from the department as to the city's preference of applicants, the city will neither support nor oppose any registration certificate application under consideration by the department. Likewise, if inquiry is made by the department, the city will abstain from endorsing any application as beneficial to the community.
( Ord. No. 2021-11 , 9-6-2021)

No more than one cannabis dispensaries shall be allowed to operate in the city at any time.
( Ord. No. 2021-11 , 9-6-2021)

A.
Each license expires one year from the date of issuance and may be renewed only by making application as provided in 15.16.040. Application for renewal must be submitted at least 30 days before the expiration date. The license holder must continue to meet the license requirements to be eligible for a renewal.
B.
The renewal fee is $20,000.00 The city will reimburse $10,000.00 for applicants who fail to obtain a renewal of their registration certificate from the department.
C.
Failure to renew a license in accordance with this section may result in additional fees. Upon expiration of the license, the city may order closure of the cannabis establishment.
D.
If a license holder has not operated an establishment for which it holds a license in the preceding 12 months, the license will not be renewed.
( Ord. No. 2021-11 , 9-6-2021)

A.
A license may be suspended if the license holder or an employee or agent of the license holder:
1.
Violates or is otherwise not in compliance with any section of this article.
2.
Consumes or smokes or allows any person to consume or smoke cannabis on the premises of the cannabis establishment.
3.
Knowingly dispenses or provides cannabis or cannabis products to an individual or business to whom it is unlawful to provide cannabis or cannabis products.
B.

The license holder allows a public nuisance to continue after notice from the city.

A.

The city council of the City of Selby enacts the following licensing ordinances in order to ensure that cannabis establishments within the municipal boundaries of the city operate in a manner which complies with state laws and regulations, protects the health, safety, and welfare of the general public, prevents potential conflicts and issues arising from ownership and employees, recognizes certain safety and security considerations, and minimizes risk of unauthorized use or access of cannabis by the general public.

Sec. 5.16.020. - Definitions.
SHARE LINK TO SECTION
PRINT SECTION
DOWNLOAD (DOCX) OF SECTIONS
EMAIL SECTION
Unless an alternative definition is explicitly stated in this section, this chapter utilizes the definitions for cannabis-related terms which are defined by SDCL 34-20G-1.
Cannabis (or marijuana): All parts of any plant of the genus cannabis, whether growing or not, in its natural and unaltered state, except for drying or curing and crushing or crumbling. The term includes an altered state of marijuana absorbed into the human body. The term does not include fiber produced from the mature stalks of such plant, or oil or cake made from the seeds of such plant. The term does not include the plant Cannabis sativa L. and any part of that plant, including the seeds thereof and all derivatives, extracts, cannabinoids, isomers, acids, salts, and salts of isomers, whether growing or not, with a delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol concentration of not more than three-tenths of one percent on a dry weight basis.
Cannabis cultivation facility: In addition to the definition in SDCL 34-20G-1, this term is further defined as a legally licensed entity that acquires, possesses, cultivates, delivers, transfers, transports, supplies, or sells cannabis and related supplies to a cannabis establishment.
Cannabis dispensary: In addition to the definition in SDCL 34-20G-1, this term is further defined as a legally licensed entity that acquires, possesses, stores, delivers, transfers, transports, sells, supplies, or dispenses cannabis, cannabis products, paraphernalia, or related supplies and educational materials.
Cannabis establishment: Cannabis cultivation facility, a cannabis testing facility, a cannabis product manufacturing facility, or a cannabis dispensary.
Cannabis product manufacturing facility: In addition to the definition in SDCL 34-20G-1, this term is further defined as a legally licensed entity that acquires, possesses, manufactures, delivers, transfers, transports, supplies, or sells cannabis products to a cannabis dispensary.
Cannabis products: Any concentrated cannabis, cannabis extracts, and products that are infused with cannabis or an extract thereof, and are intended for use or consumption by humans. The term includes edible cannabis products, beverages, topical products, ointments, oils, and tinctures.
Cannabis testing facility: In addition to the definition in SDCL 34-20G-1, this term is further defined as a legally licensed entity legally authorized to analyze the safety and potency of cannabis.
Department: The South Dakota Department of Health
( Ord. No. 2021-11 , 9-6-2021)

EMAIL SECTION
The city council of the City of Selby enacts the following licensing ordinances in order to ensure that cannabis establishments within the municipal boundaries of the city operate in a manner which complies with state laws and regulations, protects the health, safety, and welfare of the general public, prevents potential conflicts and issues arising from ownership and employees, recognizes certain safety and security considerations, and minimizes risk of unauthorized use or access of cannabis by the general public.
( Ord. No. 2021-11 , 9-6-2021)
Sec. 5.16.020. - Definitions.
SHARE LINK TO SECTION
PRINT SECTION
DOWNLOAD (DOCX) OF SECTIONS
EMAIL SECTION
Unless an alternative definition is explicitly stated in this section, this chapter utilizes the definitions for cannabis-related terms which are defined by SDCL 34-20G-1.
Cannabis (or marijuana): All parts of any plant of the genus cannabis, whether growing or not, in its natural and unaltered state, except for drying or curing and crushing or crumbling. The term includes an altered state of marijuana absorbed into the human body. The term does not include fiber produced from the mature stalks of such plant, or oil or cake made from the seeds of such plant. The term does not include the plant Cannabis sativa L. and any part of that plant, including the seeds thereof and all derivatives, extracts, cannabinoids, isomers, acids, salts, and salts of isomers, whether growing or not, with a delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol concentration of not more than three-tenths of one percent on a dry weight basis.
Cannabis cultivation facility: In addition to the definition in SDCL 34-20G-1, this term is further defined as a legally licensed entity that acquires, possesses, cultivates, delivers, transfers, transports, supplies, or sells cannabis and related supplies to a cannabis establishment.
Cannabis dispensary: In addition to the definition in SDCL 34-20G-1, this term is further defined as a legally licensed entity that acquires, possesses, stores, delivers, transfers, transports, sells, supplies, or dispenses cannabis, cannabis products, paraphernalia, or related supplies and educational materials.
Cannabis establishment: Cannabis cultivation facility, a cannabis testing facility, a cannabis product manufacturing facility, or a cannabis dispensary.
Cannabis product manufacturing facility: In addition to the definition in SDCL 34-20G-1, this term is further defined as a legally licensed entity that acquires, possesses, manufactures, delivers, transfers, transports, supplies, or sells cannabis products to a cannabis dispensary.
Cannabis products: Any concentrated cannabis, cannabis extracts, and products that are infused with cannabis or an extract thereof, and are intended for use or consumption by humans. The term includes edible cannabis products, beverages, topical products, ointments, oils, and tinctures.
Cannabis testing facility: In addition to the definition in SDCL 34-20G-1, this term is further defined as a legally licensed entity legally authorized to analyze the safety and potency of cannabis.
Department: The South Dakota Department of Health
( Ord. No. 2021-11 , 9-6-2021)

A.
There is hereby adopted by the city council rules and regulations for the purpose of governing the installation and inspection of underground sprinkler systems within and without the City of Selby connected to the city water system or private wells, including permits and penalties.
B.
A building permit shall be obtained by any person from the city finance officer prior to the installation of an underground sprinkler system.
C.
All installations shall comply with the requirements of the South Dakota State Plumbing Commission Rules and the National Standard Plumbing Code, 1990 Edition and amendments thereto.
D.
All connections to the city water system or private wells shall be inspected by a licensed plumber prior to use.
E.
Within six months all underground sprinkler systems presently in existence shall be inspected by a municipal officer or agent or licensed plumber for certification that all necessary backflow and safety valves are properly installed. If such items are missing then they shall be installed and if not, the person owning the property which is not in compliance with this chapter shall be entitled to an immediate hearing to determine if noncompliance warrants the city to discontinue water service to the residence or business until such time as the underground sprinkler system complies with this chapter. The city may discontinue water service to any residence or business not in compliance with this chapter. All owners of existing sprinkler systems shall notify the city of their system immediately.
(Adopted by Ord. 139 on 10/5/1992)

It shall be unlawful for any person owning, leasing, occupying, or having charge of possession of any premises in the city to keep or maintain such premises in a manner which is at variance with and inferior to the level or maintenance of surrounding properties. The following condition or conditions constitute such a variance and are declared a public nuisance.
A.
Overgrown (as defined as more than five-inches in length) vegetation, grass, or weeds, which are unsightly and/or likely to harbor rats or vermin;
B.
Dead decayed, or diseased trees, weeds, and other vegetation;
C.
Lumber, junk, old iron, cement slabs, trash, tires, debris, salvage materials or anything whatsoever in which rodents may live or breed, maintained upon any premises which is visible from a public street, alley, or adjoining property;
The property owner has seven days after being contacted by the city to abate the nuisance. In the event that the nuisance is not abated, the city will, abate the nuisance and assess the cost of the same against the property owner or persons in possession. The hourly rate charged by the city is $250.00 for the first hour and an additional $100.00 per additional hour.
Notice will be given only once annually; and further violations of grass more than five inches before October 31 shall result in the city council causing further abatement thereof without additional notice.
(Ord. No. 2019-002 , 10-2-2019; Ord. No. 2019-003 , 10-2-2019)

The city council members of Selby shall constitute the board of health.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 171 on 11/4/2002)
State Law reference— SDCL 9-32-1; SDCL 9-32-2.

Every physician attending any patient within this city shall, within 24 hours after he shall have first attended or prescribed for such person or patient, report to the board of health of the City of Selby, in writing, every person or patient having any contagious, pestilential or infectious disease, with his or her place of dwelling, and name, together with the name or type of disease, and he shall also immediately report in writing, to said board of health, the death of any of his patients who shall have died within the city of such contagious, infectious, or pestilential disease, and to state the name and type of such disease. And for the purpose of this chapter the words "contagious, infectious and pestilential disease" shall include any and all other diseases publicly declared by the board of health dangerous to the public health.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 171 on 11/4/2002)
State Law reference— SDCL 9-32-1; SDCL 9-32-2.

No child, minor, or other person from any house where any person is sick with any contagious, infectious or pestilential disease, shall attend any public, private or sectarian school in this city until the recovery or death of the sick person or persons as the case may be, nor until provided with a permit in writing, signed by the attending physician, if any, and the board of health of the city, which permit must be presented to the principal or teacher of said public or private school before such child, minor or other person shall be allowed to remain; and it shall be the duty of all attending physicians to inform the parents or guardian of any child or minor who may be residing at the infected premises, of the provisions of this section; and it shall be the duty of any principal or teacher of any school in this city to report at once, in writing, to the board of health any of the violations of the provisions of this section.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 171 on 11/4/2002)
State Law reference— SDCL ch. 9-32 in general.

Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who shall resist any of the provisions of any section of this chapter, or who shall refuse or neglect to obey any of the rules, orders, or sanitary regulations of the board of health of this city, or who shall resist any board of health member of this in carrying out the provisions of this chapter, or any part thereof, shall, upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a fine not less than $5.00 nor more than $200.00, together with the costs of prosecution for each and every offense. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons within the City of Selby to keep, maintain or have in his custody or under his control any dog or cat without first having obtained a license so to do from the city finance officer, as hereafter provided, and without having paid the license fee therefor.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 190 on 7/2/2007)

Any person or persons desiring to keep, maintain or have in his custody by himself or agent within the said City of Selby any dog or cat, shall on or before the 30th day of April in each year make application to the city finance officer for a license to keep such dog or cat. Such application shall be in writing stating the name, sex, color and other distinguishing characteristics of said dog or cat and the name of the owner thereof, and that the dog or cat has no vicious propensities so far as known to said applicant or to any other interested party. Such application shall be made on printed forms furnished by the city finance officer and shall be filed with the city finance office. In addition, the person desiring to license the said dog or cat shall furnish proof from a licensed veterinarian that the said dog or cat has been immunized for rabies within the past 24 months.
In the event the city finance officer has in his possession a signed complaint or complaints verified by the chief of police that such dog or cat has vicious propensities, such application shall be denied, and the owner or person having control of such dog or cat shall cause the same to be removed from the corporate city limits.
Any person violating the provisions of chapter 9.04 shall be fined in a sum not exceeding the amount of $100.00. Each day the violation continues constitutes a separate offense.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 190 on 7/2/2007)

Effective May 1, 2013, the applicant shall at the time of making such application pay to the city finance officer as a license fee the sum of $10.00 for each dog or cat for which such license is sought, and it shall be the duty of the city finance officer at the time of issuance of the license herein provided for to furnish and deliver to said applicant a metallic tag for each dog or cat for which such license is issued upon which tag shall be stamped or engraved, the registered number of the dog or cat and the year when registered. It shall be the duty of the owner of the dog or cat to place a collar around the neck of such dog or cat securely fastened with the tag furnished by the city finance officer. In case of the loss of any tag so issued, the city finance officer is authorized to issue a replacement thereof upon payment to him in the sum of $2.00, application being made therefor, upon satisfactory proof that such tag has been lost.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 190 on 7/2/2007; Amended by Ord. 218 on 3/4/2013)

It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to permit or suffer to run at large within the limits of the City of Selby, any dog or animal of a destructive habit or vicious disposition, or which is in the habit of destroying or depositing waste on shrubbery, flowers, gardens, etc., or that may be in the habit of barking at or in any manner annoying any person or persons living in the immediate neighborhood or passing along or using the streets or sidewalks of said city, after being notified in writing that such dogs or animals possess such habits. Any police officer or person of proper authority, is authorized and empowered to capture any such dog or animal found running at large in said city after the owner or keeper thereof or the person having the custody of said dog or animal has been notified of such habit. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined a sum not exceeding the sum of $100.00.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 190 on 7/2/2007)

The mayor of the city may, by proclamation at any time, upon 48 hours' notice, publish in the official paper of the city, an order that all dogs in the City of Selby are to be muzzled in such a manner as to make it impossible for said dogs to bite any person, dog, or other animal.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 190 on 7/2/2007)

The chief of police is hereby authorized to employ, whenever he may deem it necessary, a sufficient number of persons to capture, kill and dispose of all dogs running at large contrary to the provisions of this chapter. It shall be the duty of the person in charge to destroy such dog and to cause it to be removed and properly buried.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 190 on 7/2/2007)

No dog of dangerous, vicious or fierce propensities may be at large at any time within the limits of the city, and it shall be unlawful for the owner or other person having any such dog in his or her possession or under his or her control, within the city limits.
A.
If any dog attacks, bites or attempts to bite any person while such dog is at large, then such dog shall be conclusively presumed to be a dangerous dog and a dog of dangerous propensities.
B.
If any dog attacks or attempts to attack any other dog or any other animal while such dog is at large, or chases, or otherwise attempts to catch a person, then such dog shall be conclusively presumed to be a vicious dog and have vicious propensities.
C.
Upon written or other complaint or other reasonable cause, arising out of either subsections A. or B. above, a police officer of this city may destroy any dog having dangerous or vicious propensities, without having to catch or impound such dog, even if the animal is running at large, or upon the premises of such owner or person having control.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 190 on 7/2/2007)

The city police officer or an animal control officer of the city is hereby authorized, upon complaint of a resident of said city, to catch upon the property of the complainant, such cats as may be causing a nuisance thereon and impound such cats in a suitable place for the care of the animal. Any cat caught pursuant to this section which has a collar and valid rabies vaccination tag shall be released to the owner.
(Adopted by Ord. 148 on 10/16/1995; Amended by Ord. 190 on 7/2/2007)

Upon impoundment of a cat without a collar and valid rabies vaccination tag, the animal control officer or city police officer shall post written notice at the city finance office, describing the cat and stating the approximate time and place where such cat was apprehended, and how the same may be recovered by the owner. Unless recovered by the owner, said cat may be sold or destroyed in the most humane manner possible after the expiration of four days from the time when the notice of apprehension and the impoundment was given or posted.
(Adopted by Ord. 148 on 10/16/1995; Amended by Ord. 190 on 7/2/2007)

Any ordinance or part of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this chapter are hereby repealed. The invalidity of any section, clause, sentence or provision of this chapter shall not affect the validity of any other part of this chapter which can be given affect without such invalid part or parts.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 190 on 7/2/2007)

A.
Keeping of livestock prohibited. No person may keep any horse, cow, swine, goat, sheep, or other livestock or erect or maintain any building or enclosure for use in keeping of such animals within the jurisdictional limits of the City of Selby.
B.
Keeping of fowl and game birds prohibited. No person may keep any chickens, guinea fowl, ducks, geese, turkeys, or other domestic fowl or game birds. including, but not limited to, pheasants. clucks, quail and partridge, within the jurisdictional limits of the City of Selby.
C.
Keeping of bees prohibited. No person may keep or have any bees or hives or bees within the jurisdictional limits of the City or Selby.
D.
Livestock running at large. No person may allow any horses, cattle, swine, sheep, and goats to run or be at large within the jurisdictional limits of the City of Selby.
E.
Penalty. Fine will be assessed as per the City of Selby Fine/Bond Schedule.
(Adopted by Ord. 222 on 6/1/2015)

Before a dog or cat license is issued or any dog or cat, the owner must present evidence with the application for the license that the dog or cat has been vaccinated against rabies. Such evidence shall be the certificate of vaccination signed by a licensed veterinarian, and the certificate shall show that the vaccination does not expire within 12 months from the effective date of the dog or cat license.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 148 on 10/16/1995; Amended by Ord. 190 on 7/2/2007)

Any person, firm, or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall upon conviction thereof, be punished of the fine of not less than $5.00 nor more than $100.00, or by imprisonment in jail not to exceed 30 days or by both such fine and imprisonment.
(Adopted by Ord. 1989 Municipal Code Book on 1/17/1990; Amended by Ord. 190 on 7/2/2007)

Any person or persons desiring to keep, maintain or have in his custody by himself or agent within the said City of Selby any dog or cat, shall on or before the 30th day of April in each year make application to the city finance officer for a license to keep such dog or cat. Such application shall be in writing stating the name, sex, color and other distinguishing characteristics of said dog or cat and the name of the owner thereof, and that the dog or cat has no vicious propensities so far as known to said applicant or to any other interested party. Such application shall be made on printed forms furnished by the city finance officer and shall be filed with the city finance office. In addition, the person desiring to license the said dog or cat shall furnish proof from a licensed veterinarian that the said dog or cat has been immunized for rabies within the past 24 months.
In the event the city finance officer has in his possession a signed complaint or complaints verified by the chief of police that such dog or cat has vicious propensities, such application shall be denied, and the owner or person having control of such dog or cat shall cause the same to be removed from the corporate city limits.

Title 10 - TRANSPORTATION CODE
